ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle:
Structure and optical property changes of Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
particles by Q-switched laser pulses in water

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Materials and Optoelectronic Science
Department of Mechanical and Automation Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Monoclinic H-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powders subjected to Q-switched laser pulses in water were characterized by X-ray/electron diffraction and optical spectroscopy to have a significant optical property change with accompanied transformation into orthorhombic T-, pseudohexagonal TT-type and an amorphous phase. The T-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles were (100), (010), (001) and (
$$\overline{2} $$
2 ¯
01) faceted and commonly in oriented intergrowth with TT-type or amorphized domains retaining the polymerized block units of the relic H-type. Such multiple-phase nanoparticles were hydrogenated and densified to modify Raman and FTIR bands and to show visible absorptions corresponding to a broad minimum band gap of 2.3–2.8 eV for potential opto-catalytic and electrochromic applications.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
forms a number of crystalline polymorphs, having Nb atoms mainly in coordination number (CN) of 6, at different temperatures under ambient pressure condition. These polymorphs have been named by the high-, moderate- (800–1,000
$$^{\,\circ }$$
∘
C) and low-formation temperatures in German (i.e. hoch-, moderat- and tief-) as monoclinic H-, monoclinic M- and orthorhombic T-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
, respectively [1]. In fact, the H-type has the space group
$$P2(3)$$
P 2 ( 3 )
(JCPDS 37-1468) and the T-type has the space group Pbam (JCPDS 27-1003) which is closely related to a pseudohexagonal TT-type with the space group
$$P$$
P
(JCPDS 28-0317) according to structure refinements of niobium pentoxide [2]. Static compression experiments at temperatures further indicate that as pressure increases, the H-type transforms into T-type, platy (blätter) B-type with monoclinic structure [3] and then Z-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
with Nb atoms in CN of 7 such as that synthesized at 5–8 GPa and 600–1,300
$${^\circ }$$
∘
C [4].

Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
was also known as an n-type semiconductor having a wide band gap 3.4 eV in bulk H-type structure [5]. A number of chemical and physical methods have been used to fabricate Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
as various nanostructures, such as thin film [6, 7], nanorods [8] and nanowires [9], for industrial applications. Such Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanostructures have found applications in field emission [9], gas sensing [10, 11] and as electrochromic material [6].

Pulsed laser ablation (PLA) of solid target in liquid (PLAL) has been a convenient dynamic method in metal and metal oxide nanocrystal synthesis and semiconductor nanostructure fabrication [12]. Such a simple physical chemical process was commonly adopted for the fragmentation of noble metals [13–17]. The PLAL process was particularly useful to synthesize and quench dense nanoparticles such as diamond [18], SnO
$$_{2}$$
2
with
$$\alpha $$
α
-PbO
$$_{2}$$
2
-type structure [19] and CaCO
$$_{3}$$
3
with high-pressure stabilized calcite II structure [20] taking advantage of the rapid radiant cooling rate for the nanoparticles [21]. Here, H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powders were subjected to Q-switched laser pulses in water to fabricate and quench the hydrogenated Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles with specific high-pressure structures, facets and optical properties for potential optoelectronic applications.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para:
A fixed amount (0.01 g) of whitish Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5 }$$
5
powder (Mitsui Chemicals, chemically pure, micrometers in size with well-developed (101) face and fault (Appendix) in accordance with the known twin plane [22]) in a silica test tube (8 mm in inner diameter and 10 cm in length) was combined with de-ionized water of specified heights (10 and 15 mm) for a total concentration of 3.2 and 2.1 mg cc
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
, respectively. The colloidal suspensions thus prepared were subjected to energetic Nd-YAG-laser (Lotis, 1064 nm, beam mode: TEM00) pulse irradiation for 30 min. In such experiments, laser beam was focused to a spot size of 0.03 mm
$$^{2}$$
2
on specified water height below water level (i.e. water/focus heights 10 and 15 mm) under laser pulse energy of 400 mJ/pulse using second harmonic excitation, i.e. 532 nm for better laser penetration in water. The Q-switch mode for specified pulse duration of 16 ns was adopted to achieve a peak power density of 8.35
$$\,\times \,$$
×
10
$$^{10}$$
10
W cm
$$^{-2}$$
- 2
(average power density 1.33
$$\times $$
×
10
$$^{4 }$$
4
W cm
$$^{-2})$$
- 2
)
at 10 Hz. Water refill and suspension shaking after every 5 min of PLA procedure were employed to ensure a uniform colloidal suspension upon energetic irradiation for an accumulated time of up to 30 min. The resultant colloidal suspension became grayish and warmed up to ca. 50
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C.

The sample of particles centrifuged from the colloidal suspension for a much larger quantity was then deposited on glass for X-ray diffraction (XRD, SIEMENS D5000, Cu K
$$\alpha $$
α
at 40 kV, 30 mA and 3 s for each 0.05
$$^\circ $$
∘
increment from
$$15^\circ $$
15 ∘
up to
$$65^\circ $$
65 ∘
of 2
$$\theta $$
θ
angle). The composition and crystal structures of the individual condensates collected on Cu grids overlaid with a carbon-coated collodion film were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL 3010 at 200 kV) coupled with bright field image (BFI), selected area electron diffraction (SAED) and point-count energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis at a beam size of 5 nm.

The UV–visible absorption of the colloidal suspension as formed by PLA was characterized by the instrument of U-3900H, Hitachi, with a resolution of 0.1 nm in the range of 190–900 nm. Raman spectra of the centrifuged condensates were made using He–Ne laser excitation (633 nm) having a spatial resolution of 1
$$\upmu $$
μ
m (HORIBA HR800) for the study of structure units in the condensates. The centrifuged condensates were also mixed with KBr for Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Bruker 66v/S, 64 scans in the range of 400–4,000 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
with 4 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
resolution) study of H
$$^{+ }$$
+
signature and structure change of the Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder subjected to PLA in water.

Section2.Heading: X-ray diffraction
Section2.Para:
The compiled XRD traces in Fig. 1 showed that the starting Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder of the H-type structure (Fig. 1a) has partially transformed into T-, TT- and an amorphous phase after PLA at specified water/focus heights and irradiation time (Fig. 1b–f). (It should be noted that the T- and TT-type phases were unambiguously identified by later electron diffraction and lattice imaging even though the weak diffractions of the two phases appeared to be nearly superimposed in the XRD traces, e.g. (001)
$$_\mathrm{T}$$
T
/(001)
$$_{\mathrm{TT}}$$
TT
, (200)
$$_\mathrm{T}$$
T
/(100)
$$_{\mathrm{TT}}$$
TT
and (181)
$$_\mathrm{T}$$
T
/(101)
$$_{\mathrm{TT}}$$
TT
diffractions in Fig. 1b–e.) For the case of 10 mm water/focus height (i.e. 3.2 mg cc
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
concentration), it took 10 min of irradiation time for the H-type powder to change significantly into the T- and TT-type structures (Fig. 1b) and 20 min for almost complete amorphization (Fig. 1c). As for the case of 15 mm water/focus height (i.e. 2.1 mg cc
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
concentration), it took 10 min for the H-type powder to change significantly into the T- and TT-type structures (Fig. 1d), 20 min for partial amorphization (Fig. 1e) and 30 min for complete amorphization (Fig. 1f). Thus, a longer irradiation time or a higher concentration of the colloidal suspension (i.e. more effective particle collisions) has caused more extensive amorphization of the Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder in water.

Section2.Heading: TEM
Section2.Para:
TEM BFI and corresponding SAED pattern coupled with diffraction intensity profile (Fig. 2) of a representative sample subjected to PLA at 15 mm water/focus height for 20 min showed the nanosized (
$$<$$
<
40 nm) and agglomerated/coalesced particles (Fig. 2a) of crystalline TT-, T- and H-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
in random orientation with characteristic diffractions and an additional amorphous phase with diffuse diffraction intensity (Fig. 2b). The T-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticle typically showed well-developed (100), (201) and (001) facets as shown in the lattice image and 2-D Fourier transform in the [010] zone axis (Fig. 3). By contrast, the amorphous nanoparticles tended to be spherical to minimize the total surface energy. Occasionally, the T- and TT-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5 }$$
5
nanoparticles were found to coalesce with each other following partial epitaxial relationship, i.e. with the [010]
$$_{\mathrm{T}}$$
T
and [101]
$$_{\mathrm{TT}}$$
TT
zone axes in parallel (Fig. 4).

Lattice image of another sample, i.e. subjected to PLA at 10 mm water/focus height for 10 min, also showed the T-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticle with well-developed (100), (
$$\overline{2} $$
2 ¯
01) and (001) facets, in contrast to the spherical shape of the amorphous nanoparticles (Fig. 5). A closer scrutiny of such faceted T-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticle in the [010] zone axis indicated it was in fact locally amorphized or distorted as TT-type intergrowth having its principal lattice planes intersected in oblique angle different from the case of orthogonal lattice planes characteristic of the T-type matrix (Fig. 6). The amorphized domains appeared to have the polymerized block units (i.e.
$$3\,\times \,4$$
3
×
4
and/or
$$3\,\times \,5$$
3
×
5
octahedra linkage) of the high-temperature stabilized H-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
[25] as discussed in latter section.

$$_{2}$$

$$_{2}$$

$$_{2}$$
2
O

It is noteworthy that TEM observations indicated the particles are
$$<$$
<
40 nm in size, except minor H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
relic of submicron size, for all the samples subjected to PLA in water. However, XRD indicated that the particles were progressively smaller in size, as manifested by diffraction broadening, and transformed partially into to T-/TT-phase before extensive amorphization when the accumulated irradiation time increased up to 30 min at a specified water/focus height. A lower water/focus height is more effective for such a phase transformation process. In general, a lower water/focus height is more effective for such a phase transformation process using 400 mJ pulse energy and 532 nm excitation for better laser penetration in water as mentioned. We have tried other pulse energies and excitation wavelengths to see if the size/shape and phase of the nanoparticles can be further tailored. Unfortunately, the yield of colloidal suspension was too low to give reliable analyses and observations.

Section3.Heading: Raman
Section3.Para:
The starting Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder showed the typical Raman bands of the H-type structure (Appendix), i.e. Nb–O–Nb bending (237, 262, 306 and 345 cm
$$^{-1})$$
- 1
)
, ONb
$$_{3}$$
3
stretching (470 cm
$$^{-1})$$
- 1
)
, Nb–O–Nb bridging stretching (549, 630, 656 and 672 cm
$$^{-1})$$
- 1
)
, Nb–O–Nb collinear stretching (840 cm
$$^{-1})$$
- 1
)
and Nb=O terminal antisymmetric and symmetric stretching at 900 and 992 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
, respectively [26–28]. The samples after PLA at specified water/focus height showed Raman bands characteristic of the H-, T-/TT-type and amorphous (A-) phase of Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
. The typical spectra of these phases in the sample subjected to PLA at 15 mm water/focus height (Fig. 7a–c) showed bands slightly modified from those of the calcined niobium pentoxide phases [27–29]. In general, the TT-/T-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
phases formed by the present PLA process showed Nb–O–Nb bending at 230 and 323 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
and NbO
$$_{X}$$
X
(X = 6, 7 and 8) symmetric stretching at 690 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
, the latter being broadened and shifted to near 650 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
presumably due to the combined effects of lattice hydrogenation and amorphization. (The amorphous niobium pentoxide and TT-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
have similar broad Raman band in the 680–700 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
range, but with a considerably higher wave number for the latter according to Ikeya and Senna [27]).

Raman spectra of the hydrogenated nanocondensates taken from local regions with specifically enriched phase: a H-Nb
$$_{2}$$

5

Section3.Heading: FTIR
Section3.Para:
The FTIR spectra of the starting H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder and a representative sample after PLA at 15 mm water/focus height are compiled in Fig. 8. The original H-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
showed the characteristic bands of ONb
$$_{3 }$$
3
stretching at 503.3 cm
$$^{-1 }$$
- 1
[27, 30], Nb–O asymmetric stretching at 560.5 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
[30], Nb–O–Nb bridging stretching at 500–800 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
[27, 30], Nb–O–Nb collinear stretching at 840.3 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
[27, 30], Nb–O–Nb stretching at 957.7 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
[26] as well as weak and broad O–H stretching at 3,100 and 3,500 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
due to considerable hydrogenation [30, 31]. The PLA sample, however, showed significant band splitting in the range of 500–1,000 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
because the H-type has partially changed into the T-, TT- and amorphous phase with accompanied CN change of Nb atoms with respect to the first oxygen neighbors. The deterioration of the H-phase accounts for the weakened and broadened ONb
$$_{3}$$
3
stretching at 503.3 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
, the Nb–O asymmetric stretching at 560.5 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
and various Nb–O–Nb stretching types at different wave numbers as mentioned. The enhanced bands at ca. 1,383 and 1,631 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
can be attributed to O–H bending vibrations due to OH species at the metal oxide surface and hydroxylation coordination, respectively, following the band assignment of Rodrigues and da Silva [31], whereas the enhanced absorption above 3,100 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
can be ascribed to strong O–H stretching.
Fig. 8
FTIR spectra of starting H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder and the hydrogenated Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5 }$$
5
nanoparticles with co-existing H-, TT-, T- and amorphous phases after PLA in water as the specimen in Fig. 2. Note band splitting in the range of 500–1,000 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
and the enhanced bands at ca. 1,383, 1,631 and 3,100 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
due to PLA in water (cf. text). The extra weak bands at 2,841, 2,897 and 3,011 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
are due to EtOH used for IR sample preparation

Section3.Heading: UV–visible absorption
Section3.Para:
The whitish colloidal suspension containing the original H-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder showed a strong absorbance peak at ca. 380 nm (Fig. 9a) corresponding to a minimum band gap of 3.3 eV. By comparison, the darkish colloidal Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
suspension prepared by the present PLA procedure, e.g. at 15 mm water/focus height for 20 min as a representative (Fig. 9b), showed broad absorption edges in the visible range corresponding to a minimum band gap of 2.8–2.3 eV based on the curve tangent intersections with the baseline at 450–550 nm. Such a wide visible absorption edge can be attributed to the Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanocondensates of the original H-type co-existing with the newly formed T-, TT- and amorphous types as discussed later. It is noteworthy that UV absorption edge corresponding to a minimum band gap of 5.3 eV is due to the hydrogenated silica container in view of the reported band gap (in the range of 5–6 eV) for mesoporous and amorphous silica material [32] and the silica nanocondensates produced by PLA on silica powder in water [33].
Fig. 9
UV–visible absorption spectrum of a the colloidal whitish suspension containing the original H-Type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder with a strong absorbance peak at ca. 380 nm, and b the multiple phase colloidal suspension produced by PLA on H-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder in water at 15 mm water/focus height for 20 min. The visible absorption of the hydrogenated H-type and newly formed polymorphs of Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
corresponds to a minimum band gap of 2.8–2.3 eV based on its intersection with the baseline in the range of 450–550 nm. The UV absorption of silica container corresponds to a minimum band gap of 5.3 eV based on its intersection with the baseline at 234 nm

Section2.Heading:
Phase selection by PLA on H-Nb
$$_{2}\mathrm{O}_{5}$$
2
O 5
powder in water
Section2.Para:
The phase assemblages formed by PLA on H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder in water are mainly the T- and TT-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
and an amorphous phase presumably with varied extent of nonstoichiometry. The crystalline T- and TT-type nanoparticles could be nucleated homogeneously from atom clusters in the plasma plume or heterogeneously from defects, such as the (101) commensurate faults, of the H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
particles. In any case, having very rapid heating and cooling and hence densification effect of nanocondensates via the PLA process in water, the Nb atoms would tend to have relatively high CN of oxygen as the high-pressure stabilized T-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
with NbO
$$_{6 }$$
6
and NbO
$$_{7}$$
7
polyhedra [34] and TT-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
with additional NbO
$$_{8}$$
8
hexagonal bipyramid [24, 27]. The shock wave by the PLA process in water would also exert similar stress effect as other dynamic processes, such as shock loading [35] and mechanical grinding [27, 36], to form high-pressure stabilized T- and TT-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
. It is of interest to note that bulk Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
undergoes the TT
$$\rightarrow $$
→
T
$$\rightarrow $$
→
H transformations with increasing cell volume at a higher calcination temperature [1, 2, 28, 37]. This is consistent with pressure-induced decrease of the H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
cell volume to change into the dense T-/TT-types having Nb in CN 7 and 8 instead of 6 [27, 34, 38]. Such a densification transformation involves directional displacement of Nb atoms in corner-shared NbO
$$_{6}$$
6
octahedra to form edge-shared NbO
$$_{8}$$
8
hexagonal bipyramid (see Fig. 11 of reference [27]) analogous to the chair/boat-type Peierls distortions during the wurtzite to rock salt-type transformation (and vice versa) of ZnO [39].

The amorphization of niobium oxide particles can also be attributed to shock loading by the PLA procedure in water in view of pressure-induced amorphization of crystalline materials upon explosive impact [40]. The amorphous and distorted TT-type domains being co-existent in the faceted T-type Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticle further implies that the amorphous phase is an intermediate precursor of the high-pressure TT phase as suggested by Ikeya and Senna [27]. The amorphous phase having similar Raman bands and hence CN as the TT-type with NbO
$$_{8}$$
8
besides NbO
$$_{6}$$
6
and NbO
$$_{7}$$
7
units [28] would also be densified. The amorphous phase could alternatively be induced by charged ion or electron irradiation of the crystalline polymorphs. It is by no means clear if the (101) commensurate faults of the H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
facilitated shuffling of the octahedra-linked
$$3\,\times \,4$$
3
×
4
and
$$3\,\times \,5$$
3
×
5
block units for disordering upon particle collisions in the colloidal suspension. (There are 27 Nb atoms in octahedral coordination and 1 in tetrahedral coordination for the monoclinic unit cell of H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5 }$$
5
in terms of edge-shared
$$3\,\times \,4$$
3
×
4
and
$$3\,\times \,5$$
3
×
5
block units consisting of corner-shared NbO
$$_{6}$$
6
[25].)

It is noteworthy that FTIR results (Fig. 8) indicated that the crystalline or amorphous Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles thus formed by the PLA procedure in water were significantly hydrogenated. Under middle pH condition in water, hydrogen uptake was not high enough for the Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder to change into H
$$_{4}$$
4
Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{7}$$
7
of pyrochlore-type structure, which would otherwise form by acid-promoted synthesis at temperatures [41]. (The pyrochlore-type H
$$_{4}$$
4
Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{7}$$
7
particles of micron size and octahedral shape with outstanding photocatalytic activity were formed by a one-pot hydrothermal route under the acidity-promoted effect with no aid of additives [41].)

Section2.Heading:
Habit plane selection of T-/TT-type Nb
$$_{2}\mathrm{O}_{5}$$
2
O 5
Section2.Para:
The Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles prepared by a soft chemical route have been identifed by TEM as disk-like with facets yet to be determined [42]. The present TEM observation further clarified that the predominant Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles formed by the PLA process in water have well-developed (100), (001) and (
$$\overline{2} $$
2 ¯
01) facets of the T-type structure. These facets are in accord with the favored F faces, i.e. with at least two periodic bond chains (PBC) [43] in terms of corner- or edge-shared polyhedra (NbO
$$_{6}$$
6
and NbO
$$_{7})$$
7
)
in T-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
structure [27, 34]. (These polyhedra are joined by edge or corner sharing within the (001) sheet and exclusively by corner sharing along [001] [24].)

The shape of the T-/TT-type nanoparticles could also rely on the orientation of the
$$3\,\times \,4$$
3
×
4
and/or
$$3\,\times \,5$$
3
×
5
structure units in the parental H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
lattice by epitaxial polymorphic transformation in view of their closely related structures [25, 27] as mentioned. However, we failed to find by TEM the relic H- domains in T- and/or TT- nanoparticles to see if the well-developed (100), (001) or (
$$\overline{2} $$
2 ¯
01) faces of the T-type structure have anything to do with the (101) habit plane of H-type (cf. Appendix).

Section2.Heading:
Cause and implications for a wide optical absorbance of Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
Section2.Para:
A wide visible absorption edge corresponding to a minimum band gap in the range 2.8–2.3 eV and hence dark bluish color of the colloidal suspension after PLA on H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder in water (Appendix) can be attributed to densification and phase change of the particles into T-, TT-type structures and an additional amorphous phase, all having lower band gap than that (3.4 eV) of bulk H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
[5] or that (3.3 eV) of the original H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder in this study (Fig. 9a). In this regard the H-type indeed has a wider band gap width than the dense T- and TT-type according to the UV–Vis spectra of the Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanorods (cf. Fig. 4 of reference [44]). The dense amorphous phase having similar Raman bands and hence relatively high CN as the case of TT-type, i.e. with NbO
$$_{8}$$
8
besides NbO
$$_{6}$$
6
and NbO
$$_{7}$$
7
units, is also expected to have a narrow band gap width. Besides, hydrogenation of nanosized oxide particles by the PLA process in water would also lower the minimum band gap analogous to the case of SnO
$$_{2}$$
2
[19].

The multiple phase and hydrogenated Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles with a wide visible absorption edge by the PLA procedure in water may have potential optoelectronic and catalytic applications in view of the function of Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanostructures as field emission [9], gas sensing [10, 11] and electrochromic materials [6]. The hydrogenated amorphous condensates would act as catalyst for specific chemical reactions like
$$\mathrm{Nb}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{5}\cdot n\mathrm{H_{2}O}$$
Nb 2
O 5
· n
H 2
O
[45]. It is also of interest to explore the electrochromic property of the hydrogenated Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles in the presence of foreign ions analogous to the case of TT-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
under an applied electric field or the insertion of alkali ion [30] such as by the following reaction [46]:
$$\begin{aligned}&\hbox {Nb}_{2}\hbox {O}_{5}\,(\hbox {transparent})\,+ {x{\hbox {A}}}^{+} + {x{\hbox {e}}}^{-} \leftarrow \rightarrow {A}_{x}\hbox {Nb}_{2}\hbox {O}_{5}\\&\quad (\hbox {blue}) \hbox {where}\,A\,=\,\hbox {H}^{+} \hbox { or } \hbox {Li}^{+} \end{aligned}$$
Nb 2
O 5
( transparent )
+
x A
+
+
x e
-
← →
A x
Nb 2
O 5
( blue )
where
A
=
H +
or
Li +
In this connection, our additional experiment of PLA on H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder in water spiked with NaCl showed that the resultant colloidal suspension is grayish instead of dark bluish due to less extent of hydrogenation, even though the Na
$$^{+}$$
+
uptake was negligible and the phase assemblage and size of the particles (cf. FTIR and XRD results of reference [23], not shown) remained basically the same as the present case of de-ionized water environment.

ItemContent.Para:
PLA on micrometer-sized and whitish H-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
powder at specified water/focus heights caused progressive formation of T/TT-type and amorphous nanoparticles which are dark bluish with miniature size down to ca. 5 nm.

The resultant T-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles showed (100), (001) and (201) facets in accordance with orthorhombic symmetry and F faces in terms of periodic bond chains.

The TT-type occurred as separate nanoparticles or as distorted domains retaining the
$$3\,\times \,4$$
3
×
4
and/or
$$3\,\times \,5$$
3
×
5
polymerized units within the T-Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles.

The polymorphic Nb
$$_{2}$$
2
O
$$_{5}$$
5
nanoparticles formed by the PLA process in water were hydrogenated and densified under the influence of capillarity and rapid heating–cooling effect to lower the minimum band gap down to 2.8–2.3 eV for potential opto-catalytic and electrochromic applications.
